analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received October 12, 2017; revised February 8, 2018; accepted April 21, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is focused on the observer-based adaptive fuzzy control problem for nonlinear stochastic systems with the nonstrict-feedback form, in which some complicated and challenging issues including unmeasurable states, input quantization and actuator faults are addressed. The fuzzy logic systems are introduced to approximate the nonlinear functions existing in the control system. A fuzzy observer is designed to observe the unavailable state variables. In order to handle the negative effects resulting from input quantization and actuator faults, a damping term with the estimation of unknown bounds as well as a positive time-varying integral function are constructed, respectively. Furthermore, an observer-based adaptive fuzzy control scheme is proposed for the considered systems to compensate for the effects of input quantization and actuator fault based on adaptive backstepping approach. The proposed control strategy can guarantee that all the signals in the closed-loop system are bounded. Finally, simulation results are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive control scheme.

concerning stochastic nonlinear systems becomes more and more active. Robust adaptive output feedback controllers have been designed for a class of nontriangular stochastic nonlinear systems in [5]. Both the fault detection and fault-tolerant control problems have been investigated for nonlinear stochastic systems in framework of Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model in [6]. A dissipative filter strategy has been proposed by Shi et al. [7] for fuzzy switched stochastic systems. An adaptive fuzzy outputconstrained fault-tolerant control method has been proposed for a class of nonlinear stochastic large-scale systems with actuator faults in [8].

As a structural design approach, adaptive backstepping method is to design immediate control signals and adaptive laws in every step for first n -1 subsystems, and construct the actual controller with the adaptive laws in the last step [9]- [25], which is often adopted in nonlinear stochastic systems. Deng et al. [26] proposed an adaptive control scheme for nonlinear stochastic systems by designing a novel Lyapunov function. Tong et al. [27] designed an observer to estimate the unavailable states, and proposed an outputfeedback based adaptive fuzzy tracking control method for nonlinear systems with dead zones. Since the sharp differences between the strict-feedback systems and nonstrict-feedback ones, the existing control approaches cannot be applied to nonstrict-feedback versions directly. Different from the above strict-feedback systems, the output-based adaptive control problem for nonlinear stochastic systems in the nonstrictfeedback form has been studied in [28], in which a variable separation approach was introduced to handle the difficulty arising from the nonstrict-feedback structure.

Input quantization, which is often addressed in networked systems, can map continuous signals to discrete finite sets. So far, several results concerning input quantization have been reported in [29]- [34]. To guarantee the tracking performance, a robust control scheme has been provided in [29] for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems with input quantization. In [30], a quantized H ∞ control strategy has been proposed for nonlinear stochastic time-delay systems with missing measurements. Liu et al. [31] designed a fuzzy adaptive quantized controller for a class of stochastic nonlinear uncertain systems. Xing et al. [32] proposed a novel tracking control scheme for a series of uncertain nonlinear systems with quantized input. For strict-feedback nonlinear system with nonlinearities of state quantizers, an appropriately quantized controller has been designed in [33]. The adaptive asymptotic tracking 2168-2216 c 2018 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.
control problem has been investigated in [34] for nonlinear systems in the presence of input quantization, where a tuning function control strategy was proposed.

On the other hand, actuator faults, which is a common problem in many practical industrial applications can decrease the system performance even lead to instability. Therefore, it is important to provide robust control schemes for systems against actuator fault. An adaptive fault-tolerant tracking control strategy has been proposed for multi-input and multioutput discrete-time systems via reinforcement learning algorithm with less learning parameters in [35]. Based on Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model, Jiang et al. [36] proposed an adaptive fault-tolerant control strategy, and applied it to the near-space vehicle. Considering the unavailable state variables, an output-feedback based fuzzy fault-tolerant controller has been designed for fuzzy systems in [37]. Combing the control allocation approach, Alwi and Edwards [38] proposed a sliding mode faut-tolerant control scheme. Employing the adaptive backstepping approach, Tong et al. [39] designed a decentralized adaptive fuzzy fault-tolerant controller for largescale nonlinear systems subject to unmeasurable states. The decentralized adaptive tracking fault-tolerant control problem has been investigated for stochastic systems with unmodeled dynamics in [40]. Considering a kind of nonaffine nonlinear faults, an adaptive fuzzy fault-tolerant tracking control strategy has been presented in [41]. Fault-tolerant tracking controllers of spacecraft have been designed with prescribed performance and time-varying in [42] and [43], respectively. Recently, Li and Yang [44] proposed an adaptive asymptotic faulttolerant tracking controller for nonlinear system in the presence of input quantization. However, the problem of adaptive control for nonlinear stochastic nonstrict-feedback systems, in which actuator fault, input quantization, and unavailable states occur simultaneously has not been investigated, which is an interesting yet challenging issue.

Motivated by the above discussions, this paper studies the problem of adaptive fuzzy control for nonstrict-feedback stochastic nonlinear systems with unmeasurable states, actuator faults and input quantization. Fuzzy systems are introduced to approximate unknown nonlinear functions. By employing the property of membership function, the difficulty arising from the nonstrict-feedback structure is handled. An observer is designed to estimate unavailable states. The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows.

1) An observer-based adaptive fuzzy controller is designed for stochastic nonstrict-feedback nonlinear systems, where actuator faults, input quantization, and unmeasurable states are considered in a unified framework. 2) The negative effects of input quantization and actuator fault are completely handled by introducing a damping term with the estimation of unknown bounds and a positive time-varying integral function, respectively. 3) The total number of faults considered in this paper is infinite, which is different from the existing results. 4) Simulation results are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the problem formulation and preliminaries.

Section III discusses how to design the adaptive fuzzy observer. The adaptive control scheme and stability analysis are presented in Section IV. Simulation results are given in Section V. Section VI concludes this paper.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Consider the following stochastic system with input quantization and actuator fault:
div.formula: dx i = (x i+1 + f i (x))dt + g i (y)dw dx n = ⎛ ⎝ m j=1 b j q(u j ) + f n (x) ⎞ ⎠ dt + g n (y)dw y = x 1 , i = 1, 2, . . . , n -1( 1 )
div.p: where x = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ] T ∈ R n represents the system state, y ∈ R denotes the system output. q(u j ) ∈ R represents the quantized output, where u j is the control signal to be designed, b j ∈ R is an unknown parameter with j = 1, 2, . . . , m. f i (x)(i = 1, 2, . . . , n) is an unknown smooth nonlinear function with f i (0) = 0. w is a standard Wiener process satisfying E{dw(t)} = 0. For the input quantization considered in the system (1), the following hysteresis quantization model is adopted:
div.formula: q(u j ) = ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ u i,j sgn u j , u i,j 1+δ j < u j ≤ u i,j uj < 0; or u i,j < u j ≤ u i,j 1-δ j , uj > 0 u i,j 1 + δ j sgn u j , u i,j 1-δ j < u j ≤ u i,j( 1+δ j) 1-δ j uj > 0; or u i,j < u j ≤ u i,j
div.p: 1-δ j , uj < 0 0, 0 ≤ u j < u j,min 1+δ j uj < 0; or u j,min 1+δ j ≤ u j < u j,min , uj > 0 q u j t -, uj = 0 where u i,j = ρ 1-i j u j,min , u j,min > 0 is the size of the deadzone of q(u j ). δ j = [(1 -ρ j )/(1 + ρ j )] is close to 1, ρ j ∈ (0, 1) is a measure of quantization density. To facilitate the control design, the hysteretic quantizer can be described as:
div.formula: q(u j ) = u j + ϑ j (2
div.p: where ϑ j = q(u j )u j ∈ R, ϑ j represents a nonlinear function and u j is the control signal with j = 1, 2, . . . , m. Remark 1: Even Li and Yang [44] considered the adaptive tracking control problem for a category of uncertain nonlinear system in the presence of actuator fault and input quantization, the proposed control scheme cannot be applied to our paper directly due to the sharp differences between the system in [44] and that in our paper. For systems with the nonstrictfeedback form, the nonlinear function for every subsystem comprises all state variables, it is quite different from the strictfeedback ones. If the traditional control scheme is applied to nonstrict-feedback systems, it can lead to the algebraic loop problem.
Lemma 1 [45]: The nonlinear function ϑ j satisfies the following inequalities:
div.formula: ϑ 2 j ≤ δ 2 j u 2 j ∀ u j ≥ u j,min ϑ 2 j ≤ u 2 j,min ∀ u j ≤ u j,min .(3)
div.p: Inspired by the results in [45], the fault model of the jth actuator is as follows:
div.formula: w j (t) = k jh q u j (t) + u sj,h (t) = k jh u j (t) + ϑ j + u sj,h (t), t ∈ t jh,k , t jh,e
div.p: where u sj,h (t) is an unknown piecewise continuous and bounded signal,

According to the above equation, we can know that the jth actuator fault occurs from time t jh,k to t jh,e , t j1,k represents the time when the first fault occurs on the jth actuator. The following cases are included.
1) k jh = 1 and u sj,h = 0 indicate that no fault occurs.

2) k jh = 0 and u sj,h = 0, where k jh ∈ (0, 1). This means partial fault occurs. 3) k jh = 1 and u sj,h = 0 indicate that an offset fault occurs. 4) k jh = 0 and u sj,h = 0 mean that w j is stuck at unparametrizable bounded time-varying function u sj,h (t). Considering ( 2) and ( 3), the nonlinear system (1) with the actuator faults and the input quantization can be rewritten as
div.formula: dx i = (x i+1 + f i (x))dt + g i (y)dw dx n = ⎛ ⎝ m j=1 b j k jh u j (t) + ϑ j + u sj,h (t) + f n (x) ⎞ ⎠ dt + g n (y)dw y = x 1 , i = 1, 2, . . . , n -1. (4
div.p: To facilitate obtaining the main results, the following assumptions and lemmas, which are commonly used in adaptive control results, [44], [46], are provided.
Assumption 1: For u sj,h , there exists a positive constant ūsj,h such that |u sj,h | ≤ ūsj,h .
Assumption 2: sgn(b j ) are known, for j = 1, 2, . . . , m. Assumption 3: For the function g i (y), there exists another function ḡi (y) satisfying
div.formula: g i (y) = yḡ i (y). Assumption 4: For 1 ≤ i ≤ n, there exist unknown scalars ε * i satisfying |ε i (•)| ≤ ε * i . Assumption 5: For nonlinear function f i (•), there exists a known constant l i satisfying f i (x) -f i x ≤ l i x -x , 1 ≤ i ≤ n.
div.p: Lemma 2 [47]:
div.formula: Provided that there is a C 2,1 function V(x, t) : R n × R → R + , positive constants ς 1 , ς 2 and K ∞ -functions β1 , β2 such that the following inequalities hold for ∀x 0 ∈ R n : β1 (|x|) ≤ V(x, t) ≤ β2 (|x|) LV(x, t) ≤ -ς 1 V(x, t) + ς 2
div.p: then, we can obtain
div.formula: E[V(x, t)] ≤ V(x 0 )e -ς 1 t + ς 2 ς 1 ∀t > t 0 .
div.p: Lemma 3 [48]: The following inequality holds for
div.formula: ∀(x, y) ∈ R 2 xy ≤ q ξ ξ |x| ξ + 1 ζ q ζ |y| ζ (5)
div.p: where q > 0, ξ > 1, ζ > 1, and

Generally, fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) and neural networks are often adopted to approximate them. In this paper, FLSs are utilized to identify the unknown nonlinearities, which can be described as Rule i:
div.formula: IF x 1 is M j1 , x 2 is M j2 . . . x n is M jn , THEN y is N j , j = 1, 2, . . . , N where x = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . ,
div.p: x n ] T and y denote the input and output of FLSs, respectively. The fuzzy sets as well as membership functions are represented by M jl , N j , μ M jl (x l ) and μ N j (y), respectively.
Under the center-average defuzzifier, product inference, and singleton fuzzifier, the FLSs can be described as
div.formula: y(x) = N j=1 ỹj n l=1 μ M jl (x l ) N j=1 n l=1 μ M jl (x l )
div.p: where ỹj = max y∈R u N j (y).
The fuzzy basis function ϕ j (x) is given as follows:
div.formula: ϕ j (x) = n l=1 μ M jl (x l ) N j=1 n l=1 μ M jl (x l )
div.p: Then, the FLSs are described as
div.formula: y(x) = θ * T ϕ(x)
div.p: where
The universal approximation theorem of FLSs has been proved in [49], which can be described in the following lemma.
Lemma 4: Defining as a compact of the given continuous function f (x), for any scalar δ > 0, there is an FLS such that
div.formula: sup x∈ f (x) -θ * T ϕ(x) ≤ δ.
div.p: The following stochastic system is provided for the later analysis:
div.formula: dx = f (x)dt + ψ(x)dw ∀x ∈ R n (6)
div.p: where f (x) : R n → R n and ψ(x) : R n → R n×r are locally Lipschitz concerning x, respectively. f (0) = ψ(0) = 0. Lemma 5 [44]: For any variable x and any positive uniform continuous and bounded function σ (t), the following inequality hold:
div.formula: 0 ≤ |x| - x 2 x 2 + σ 2 (t) < σ (t) with σ (t) satisfying lim t→∞ t 0 σ (s)ds ≤ σ < ∞
div.p: where σ represents any positive constant. Definition 1 [50]: Associated with (6), for any C 2,1 function V(x), the operator L is described as
div.formula: LV = ∂V(x) ∂x f (x) + 1 2 Tr ψ(x) T ∂ 2 V(x) ∂x 2 ψ(x)(7)
div.p: where Tr(•) is the trace of "•".

div.head: III. ADAPTIVE FUZZY OBSERVER DESIGN
div.p: The state variables cannot be measured directly in lots of control applications. Therefore, it is necessary to develop an effective control scheme for nonlinear systems with unavailable states. In this paper, a fuzzy observer is introduced to estimate the unavailable states as follows:
div.formula: ẋi = xi+1 + fi (x|θ i ) + l i x 1 -x1 i = 1, 2, . . . , n -1 ẋn = m j=1 b j k jh u j (t) + ϑ j + u sj,h (t) + fn x|θ n + l n x 1 -x1(8)
div.p: where xi is the estimation of x i .
Based on the description of FLSs, the nonlinear function can be approximated as
div.formula: fi x|θ i = θ T i ϕ i x .
div.p: The optimal parameter vector θ * i is defined as
div.formula: θ * i = arg min θ i ∈ i sup x∈U fi x|θ i -fi x .
div.p: The approximation errors ε i (x) are defined as
div.formula: ε i x = fi x -fi x|θ * i . (9
div.p: Define e = x -x as the observer error with e = [e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e n ] T , x = [x 1 , . . . , xn ] T . Combining the system in (1) and the designed fuzzy observer in (8), we have
div.formula: de = Ae + n i=1 B i θ T i ϕ i x + ε + F dt + g(y)dw (10

div.formula: V e = e T Pe.

where λ 0 ≤ λ min(P) λ min(Q) , λ min(P) , and λ min(Q) represent the smallest eigenvalue of matrix P and Q, respectively. ε * i and l i are positive constants with i = 1, 2, . . . , n.
Substituting the inequalities ( 12)-( 15) into (11) yields

Next, we will discuss how to design an appropriate control scheme to satisfy the desired system performance even though input quantization and actuator fault occur simultaneously.

div.head: IV. ADAPTIVE CONTROLLER DESIGN
div.p: AND STABILITY ANALYSIS This section designs the immediate control signals, actual controller, and adaptive laws as well as discuss the system performance.
The immediate control signals α 1 , α i (i = 2, . . . , n), v, and controller u j (j = 1, 2, . . . , m) are defined as follows:

div.p: where
Based on the designed immediate control signal α i in (17) as well as the adaptive law ˙ i , θi in ( 20) and ( 21), we can get
div.formula: LV i ≤ -λ i e 2 - i j=1 k j z 4 j + 1 2 i k=2 k j=1 θ T j θj 1 2 i j=1 θ T j θj + n i=1 θ T i θi - i j=1 τ j 2r j ˜ T j ˜ j - i j=1 τj 2r j θ T j θj + 1 4 z 4 i+1 + D i where D i = D i-1 + (1/4)ε * 2 1 + (1/4) * 2 1 + (1/4) i-1 j=1 * 2 j + (3/4)b i + (a i /2) + (τ i /2r i ) * 2 i + ( τi /2r i )θ * 2 i .
div.p: Step n: Similar to the above steps, dz n is expressed as
div.formula: dz n = ⎛ ⎝ m j=1 b j k jh (u j + ϑ j ) + u sj,h + l n e 1 + θ * T n ϕ n x - ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 (x 2 + f 1 (x)) -θ T n ϕ n x - 12
∂ 2 α n-1 ∂x 2 1 g T 1 (y)g 1 (y) - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi xi+1 + fi x|θ i + l i e 1 - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂θ i θi - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ i ˙ i ⎞ ⎠ dt - ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 g 1 (y)dw.
div.p: In order to cope with the unknown actuator failure, we define
div.formula: γ = inf t≥0 m j=1 b j k jh β * = 1 γ * = m j=1 b j ūsj,h + m j=1 b j k jh u j,min
div.p: where b j and k jh are unknown constants. The Lyapunov function V n is defined as
div.formula: V n = V n-1 + 1 4 z 4 n + 1 2r n ˜ T n ˜ n + 1 2r n θ T n θn + 1 2ι 1 ˜ 2 + γ 2ι 2 β2
div.p: where r n , rn , ι 1 , and ι 2 are positive constants. The derivative of V n is derived as follows:
div.formula: LV n = LV n-1 + z 3 n ⎛ ⎝ m j=1 b j k jh u j + ϑ j + u sj,h - ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 x2 + e 2 + f 1 (x) -f 1 x + ε 1 + θ * T 1 ϕ 1 x + θ * T n ϕ n x -θ T n ϕ n x + l n e 1 IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS - 12

∂ 2 α n-1 ∂x 2 1 g T 1 (y)g 1 (y) - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂θ i θi - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi xi+1 + fi x|θ i + l i e 1 - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ i ˙ i ⎞ ⎠ - 1 r n ˜ T n ˙ n - 1 ι 1 ˜ ˙ - γ ι 2 β β - 1 rn θ T n θn + 3z 2 n 2 ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 g 1 (y) 2 .
div.p: According to [44], one can get
div.formula: z 3 n m j=1 1 -δ j b j k jh u j ≤ - m j=1 b j k jh z 6 n β 2 v 2 z 6 n β 2 v 2 + σ 2 (t) ≤ - γ z 6 n β 2 v 2 z 6 n β 2 v 2 + σ 2 (t) ≤ γ σ (t) -γ z 3 n βv. (43
div.p: Combining the inequalities in ( 41)-( 43), one has
div.formula: z 3 n m j=1 b j k jh u j + k jh ϑ j + u s,jh ≤ z 3 n * + γ σ (t) -γ z 3 n βv.
div.p: Similar to step i, one has
div.formula: z 3 n θ * T n ϕ n x ≤ 1 2 a n + z 6 n 2a n * n z 3 n l n e 1 ≤ 1 2 z 6 n + 1 2 l 2 n e 2 -z 3 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 e 2 ≤ 1 2 z 6 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 2 + 1 2 e 2 -z 3 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 f 1 (x) -f 1 x ≤ 1 2 z 6 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 2 + 1 2 l 2 1 e 2 3 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 ε 1 x ≤ 3 4 z 4 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 4 3 + 1 4 ε * 4 1 -z 3 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 θ * T 1 ϕ 1 x ≤ 3 4 z 4 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 4 3 + 1 4 * 2 1 -z 3 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi θ * T i ϕ i (x) ≤ 3 4 z 4 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi 4 3 + 1 4 n-1 i=1 * 2 i z 3 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi θ T i ϕ i (x) ≤ 1 2 z 6 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi 2 + 1 2 n-1 i=1 θ T i θi -z 3 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi l i e 1 ≤ 1 2 z 6 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi 2 + 1 2 n-1 i=1 l 2 i e 2 3z 2 n 2 ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 g 1 (y) 2 ≤ 3z 4 n 4b n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 g 1 (y) 4 + 3 4 b n .
div.p: Then it yields
div.formula: LV n ≤ -λ n e 2 - n-1 i=1 k i z 4 i + 1 2 n-1 k=2 k j=1 θ T j θj - n-1 i=1 τi 2r i θ T i θi + 1 2 n-1 j=1 θ T j θj - n-1 i=1 τ i 2r i ˜ T i ˜ i + n i=1 θ T i θi + z 3 n -γβv -γ βv + 1 2 z 3 n - ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 x2 + z 3 n 2a n n + z 3 n n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi 2 - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂θ i θi - 12

∂ 2 α n-1 ∂x 2 1 g T 1 (y)g 1 (y) + z 3 n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 2 + 3z n 4 n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi 4 3 + 3 2 z n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 4 3 - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ xi xi+1 - n-1 i=1 ∂α n-1 ∂ i ˙ i + 3z 4 n 4b n ∂α n-1 ∂x 1 g 1 (y) 4 + ˜ T n r n r n 2a n z 6 n -˙ n + β ι 2 z 3 n ι 2 γ v -γ β + θ T n rn -r n z 3 n ϕ n (x) -θn + ˜ ι 1 ι 1 z 3 n -˙ + D n-1 + 1 4 ε * 2 1 + 1 4 * 2 1 + 1 4 n-1 j=1 * 2 j + 3 4 b n + 1 2 a n + γ σ (t)(44)
div.p: where
Substituting indirect control signal v, actual control signal u j , adaptive laws ˙ n , θn , ˙ , β, and v -γβv -γ βv = 0 into the inequality (44) yields
div.formula: LV n ≤ -λ n e 2 - n i=1 k i z 4 i - n i=1 τ i 2r i ˜ T i ˜ i + n + 1 2 - τ1 2r 1 θ T 1 θ1 + 1 - τn 2r n θ T n θn + n+1 j=4 j 2 - τn+3-j 2r n+3-j θ T n+3-j θn+3-j - 1 2 ˜ 2 - 1 2 β2 + D n + γ σ (t). (45
div.p: Then, (45) implies
div.formula: LV n ≤ -d 0 V n + D n + γ σ (t)(46)
div.p: where

To guarantee the stability of the system (1), we choose the parameters r1 , τ1 , rn+3-j , τn+3-j , rn , and τn to make that ( τ1 /2r 1 ) -[(n + 1)/2] > 0, [( τn+3-j )/(2r n+3-j )] -(j/2) > 0 and ( τn /2r n ) -1 > 0. Obviously, based on Lemma 2 and formula (46), one can obtain
div.formula: dE[V(t)] dt ≤ -d 0 E[V(t)] + D n + γ σ (t). (47
div.p: Integrating the inequality (47) over [0, t] yields
div.formula: 0 ≤ E[V(t)] ≤ V(0) - D n γ σ d 0 e -d 0 t + D n γ σ d 0
div.p: where σ denotes any positive constant. Therefore, the following inequality holds:
div.formula: E |z 1 | 4 ≤ E[V(t)] ≤ 8 D n + γ σ d 0 .
div.p: The proof is completed. Remark 3: Note that a novel adaptive fault tolerant control approach was proposed by exploiting the reinforcement learning algorithm for multiple-input and multiple-output nonlinear discrete-time systems in [35]. The cost function of systems was considered in this paper which is different from the traditional fault tolerant control schemes. However, it should be noted that the work [35] did not consider the problem of input quantization. We continue to investigate the problem of adaptive fault tolerant control subject to input quantization for nonlinear stochastic nonstrict-feedback system in this paper.

div.head: V. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, a numerical example is provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme in this paper. Consider the following stochastic nonlinear system in the nonstrict-feedback form:
div.formula: dx 1 = x 2 + (1 -sin(x 1 )) 2 x 2 dt + 0.5x 1 cos(x 1 )dw dx 2 = ⎛ ⎝ 2 j=1 q u j -3.5x 2 + x 1 x 2 2 ⎞ ⎠ dt + 0.1x 1 sin(2x 1 )dw y = x 1
div.p: and the fault model is given as follows:
div.formula: w j = q u j , if t ∈ [2k, 2k + 1) k jh q u j + u sj,h , if t ∈ [2k + 1, 2k + 2) (48
div.p: where j = 1, 2, k 1h = 0, u s1,h = 0.1 sin(t), k 2h = 0.5, u 2s,h = 0. From (48), it can be clearly seen that during [2k, 2k + 1), the actuator w j works well, while during [2k + 1, 2k + 2), w 1 is stuck at 0.1 sin(t), and the effectiveness of w 2 is reduced by 50%.

To approximate the nonlinear functions in the example, for i = 1, 2, 3, j = 0, ±1, ±3, ±5, ±7, ±9, the membership IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS Fig. 3. Responses of adaptive parameters. 1, and it can be clearly seen that both trajectories can converge to zero. Moreover, the state can be estimated by the designed observer effectively. The trajectories of states x 2 and its estimation x2 are plotted in Fig. 2. Fig. 3 shows the trajectories of adaptive parameters 1 , 2 , , β. In addition, Figs. 4 and5, respectively, depict the responses of the signals u j and q(u j ). From the above simulation results, we can conclude that the proposed control scheme is effective.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: The problem of adaptive fuzzy control has been investigated for nonlinear stochastic nonstrict-feedback system subject to input quantization, actuator fault and unavailable states in this paper. Through introducing the FLSs, the unknown nonlinear functions have been approximated effectively. With the designed observer, unavailable state variables have been estimated effectively, which paves a way for designing a control scheme under unmeasurable states. By employing the property of membership function, the challenging issue arising from the nonstrict-feedback structure has been solved. For the considered actuator fault and input quantization, a damping term with the estimation of unknown bounds and a positive time-varying integral function have been introduced to handle the relative problems. Moreover, an observer-based adaptive fuzzy faulttolerant control scheme has been proposed in the framework of adaptive backstepping approach, which can guarantee all the signals in the resulting closed-loop systems are bounded. Finally, simulation results have been provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the control strategy proposed in this paper. Recently, the event-triggered control problem has been widely studied because of its extensive application in practice. Our future work is to investigate event-triggered control problem for a class of stochastic nonlinear systems subject to actuator faults.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61673072 and Grant 61703051, in part by the Department of Education of Liaoning Province under Grant LZ2017001, in part by the Guangdong Natural Science Funds for Distinguished Young Scholar under Grant 2017A030306014, in part by the Department of Education of Guangdong Province under Grant 2016KTSCX030, in part by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities under Grant 2017FZA5010, and in part by the Science and Technology Planning Project of Guangdong Province under Grant 2017B010116006. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor Y.-J. Liu.

Hui Ma received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Harbin Normal University, Harbin, China, in 2016. She is currently pursuing the M.S. degree in applied mathematics with Bohai University, Jinzhou, China.

Her current research interests include fuzzy control and adaptive control for nonlinear systems. Her current research interests include fuzzy logic control, neural control, and robust control for nonlinear systems.

Lu Bai received the B.S. degree in mathematics from the Hebei Normal University for Nationalities, Hebei, China, in 2015. She is currently pursuing the M.S. degree in applied mathematics with Bohai University, Jinzhou, China.
Her current research interests include fuzzy control and adaptive control and their applications.

Hongjing Liang received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Bohai University, Jinzhou, China, in 2009, the M.S. degree in fundamental mathematics and the Ph.D. degree in control theory and control engineering from Northeastern University, Shenyang, China, in 2011 and 2016, respectively.
He is currently with Bohai University. His current research interests include multiagent systems, complex systems, and output regulation.
